Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as de0c960c4262169ea92a4b852dd5ebbe3810bf00
WARNING here. This is a 400 user error.
Done

Ideally in new code, we would be using a proper URL object (boost::urls::url).  It didn't exist at the time this was last written, which is why this code doesn't use it, but had we had that type safety, it would've make it clearer that there was an error below.
Done
Do we need to call cleanUp in this path?  CleanUp cleans the global variables, and I thought the whole point of this flow is that we're not using globals, so we can do parallel updates.
Done
Don't you need an internalError here?
Done
Same as above.
Done
Please make this lambda a proper function.
Done
I don't see handling for bad inputs.  If you input a target that doesn't exist, this isn't going to work.
Done
Please wrap this in an RAII class (take a look at something like TemporaryFile in the unit tests for inspiration) so that we're not having to chase down close() calls in all the exit paths.
Done
write returns an ssize_t, but then we're casting length to an int?  This looks like it will cause warnings on some combination of 32/64 bit.  PTAL and see if this is what you intended

This is going to require 2X the memory of the image, which in the past has caused OOM crashes when we've done it on accident.  Please come up with a solution that doesn't require 2X the memory to actually do the copy.  Probably you're going to have to copy in X KB chunks, while shrinking the file.

At some point we'll have direct file uploads working with all this stuff wired into http body, but until we do, we have to be somewhat careful.
Even in the existing code we follow the same technique. I suppose this is an optimization we can handle as part of a separate patch.

I made this change to handle following warning, hence i converted the unsigned int to int through static_cast.

error: comparison of integer expressions of different signedness: 'ssize_t' {aka 'long int'} and 'std::basic_string_view<char>::size_type' {aka 'long unsigned int'} [-Werror=sign-compare]
Right, so you should cast to the type being returned to ssize_t, not to int.
What is the timeframe you suspect you'll be able to write that optimization patch if I let it push to a later patchset?
Done

I can start working on it after we are done with this patch, but i will need help with ideas on how to do it since the input here is a string_view so i am not sure how we can discard the already read portions of it to avoid double copy.
Pass the string by std::string, and do something like:
Sure, in a new patch i can start with basic solution and we can iterate over it in feedback.
Missing close for fd.
Done
Please handle your errors.  If you're intentionally ignoring the return code here, leave a comment describing why.
Done
nit, this is going to silently remove duplicates, which arguably we should log an error for.
Done
Targets is a set of Redfish URLs, not dbus paths.  Why are we parsing them as dbus paths?

Changed to parse as URLs instead.
FYI: I am extracting the swid from Redfish URLs as we its being done here -

https://grok.openbmc.org/xref/openbmc/bmcweb/redfish-core/lib/update_service.hpp?r=62598e31&fi=softwareInterfaceAdded#981

= std::move(targetSet)

(Static analyzers will complain about this being a copy).
Done

we need more validation than this, if I update

/foo/<valid filename>

This will hand the request out to dbus as if it's correct.  I suspect we need to check these that they start with /redfish/v1/UpdateService/FirmwareInventory/<thing>
Sure, added it to extractMultipartUpdateParameters.
this got moved into updateMultipartContext, I'm assuming you didn't mean to add it back here.
Done, dropped it.
Addressed and replied to your comments. Thanks
Looks like the above block of code was grabbed from here.  Can we avoid duplicating this logic please, and just make the old path call the method you broke out?
The values being set in new method are different since they are specific to Update interface ApplyTime values.
Understood.  FIne as is.
We broke this method out to handle parsing, but it looks like we left the old code for checking /redfish/v1/Managers/bmc in place?  Should that be lifted into this new method?
Done
Done

The old code accepted Managers/bmc as a target.  Do we have confidence that Redfish specifies accepting these with FirmwareInventory as the target?  Do we have examples anywhere we can link in the commit message?

At the very least, we should support the old way of using the bmc as the target, even if it's wrong.  We don't want to break working code.

I couldn't find any examples in the Redfish UpdateService white paper but schema description says both software inventory instance or their related items are valid, so both seems to be allowed.
As per Mike perhaps both are valid https://redfishforum.com/post/4052/thread. I think using FirmwareInventory as the target seems like a better option as they seem to have a direct relation to update process. Please let me know your thoughts?

> I couldn't find any examples in the Redfish UpdateService white paper but schema description says both software inventory instance or their related items are valid, so both seems to be allowed.

Can you link that in your commit message?

> As per Mike perhaps both are valid https://redfishforum.com/post/4052/thread. I think using FirmwareInventory as the target seems like a better option as they seem to have a direct relation to update process. Please let me know your thoughts?

Geez, ok, so either is valid.  That's not very intuitive, and I suspect at some point we'll have to support the "point to device" variant.

Can we at least get the old /redfish/v1/Managers/<bmc> supported through this so when we transition we don't break existing users?
Done

Please don't capture req in an async lambda, especially by value.  You probably want to create your task::Payload object here, which avoids making a copy of the whole request, and only copies the values that are needed.
Done
Are we sure this works?  This is going to call close() on the fd after we start the update, presumably we just gave that fd to dbus?
Yes, it has been working. Probably, you are referring to passing the memfd to the handleStartUpdate call so we don't loose reference until callback returns?

I'm referring to the fact that close is going to be called on this, but dbus must be calling dup() somewhere internally.

ACK.
follow the Naming convention please
Done
Insert returns a bool that will tell you whether or not the key already existed.  Use that for this condition instead to avoid duplicating the lookup.
Done
operator[] creates if the key doesn't exist.  Presumably here you want find()
Done
I'm not quite following this, you're looking for the path associated with the ObjectManager?  Presumably you want something associated with the software version itself?
I am looking for the StartUpdate interface somewhere on "/xyz/openbmc_project/software" which is associated with swObjectPath (i.e. the Software Version Object Path).
gotcha.
I don't see any shared ownership here.  Any reason this needs to be a shared_ptr?

> I tried making this a unqiue_pointer and passing it the call stack using std::move but i am hitting assertion for memfd not being not copy constructible issue.

I would expect that this could just be passed by value with std::move(), but sure, unqiue_ptr works.

> My understanding is that this happens because of how lambda captures the resulting closure object. For example, i had tried this -
> 
> inline void
>     getSwInfo(const std::shared_ptr<bmcweb::AsyncResp>& asyncResp,
>               const crow::Request& req,
>               std::unique_ptr<MemoryFileDescriptor> memfd,
>               const std::string& applyTime,
>               const std::vector<boost::urls::url>& targets)
>               const boost::system::error_code& ec,
>               const dbus::utility::MapperGetSubTreePathsResponse& subtree)
> {
>    ...
> }
> 
> auto memfd = std::make_unique<MemoryFileDescriptor>("update-image");
> ...
> dbus::utility::getSubTreePaths(
>         "/xyz/openbmc_project/software", 1, interfaces,
>         [asyncResp, req, memfd=std::move(memfd), applyTimeNewVal,
>          targets](const boost::system::error_code& ec,
>                   const dbus::utility::MapperGetSubTreePathsResponse& subtree) {
>         getSwInfo(asyncResp, req, std::move(memfd), applyTimeNewVal, targets, ec, subtree);

const dbus::utility::MapperGetSubTreePathsResponse& subtree) <ADD the keyword mutable right here>


lambdas pass by const values by default.  you need the word mutable to make it pass by non-const value, so you can do a std::move()

I tried changing the memfd to pass by value with std::move(), but i noticing use after free issue in warnings, which seems like a valid issue? So, i am thinking i need to move this back to a shared_ptr. I am also noticing a similar issue use after move issue for payload?

../redfish-core/lib/update_service.hpp:903:69: error: the parameter 'memfd' is copied for each invocation but only used as a const reference; consider making it a const reference [performance-unnecessary-value-param,-warnings-as-errors]
  903 |                         task::Payload payload, MemoryFileDescriptor memfd,
      |                                                                     ^
      |                                                const               &
../redfish-core/lib/update_service.hpp:912:38: error: std::move of the const variable 'payload' has no effect; remove std::move() or make the variable non-const [performance-move-const-arg,-warnings-as-errors]
  912 |         handleStartUpdate(asyncResp, std::move(payload), objectPath, ec1,
      |                                      ^~~~~~~~~~       ~
../redfish-core/lib/update_service.hpp:1010:43: error: 'payload' used after it was moved [bugprone-use-after-move,-warnings-as-errors]
 1010 |             [asyncResp, payload(std::move(payload)), memfd = std::move(memfd),
      |                                           ^
../redfish-core/lib/update_service.hpp:1010:25: note: move occurred here
 1010 |             [asyncResp, payload(std::move(payload)), memfd = std::move(memfd),
One sec, let me just push a patch with what I think should work.  That's probably easier than explaining it here.
NVM about the path; see my other comment, I understand why we're hitting these issues.
Sure and yes we are hitting because of std::move happening in a loop.
Can we wrap this in your class please?
Done
I think we want depth 1 here?
Done
Addressed and replied to comments. Thanks

can you code golf this a little?

this check is duplicated between the branches.
Done
Split into multiple branches to make this readable.
Done

You've decoded this url twice in your flow.  On line 777, your call has already parsed out the ID of the uri, you need to just push that inyour your vector instead of the full URI, then you avoid having to do this conversion, which as written a url object isn't required to have back().
Done
Addressed & replied to comments, please check.
Done

ok, I understand now;  The shared ownership is happening here, where each loop gets its own copy of the payload.

Yes, shared_ptr is reasonable in this case.

I thought we talked about getting this new API working for a single target, then change it to work with multiple targets later?  Your testing mentioned in the commit message also implies that we haven't attempted multiple targets yet, and the existing task system won't be able to support multiple tasks in flight, because like we talked about on discord, you can't return multiple "tasks" in a single HTTP response, so we'll need some sort of SubTask implementations for this to work properly.  That's more than I think we should put in one commit, so lets just simplify this for now down to a single target allowed and get it on master so we can unblock the other things adding your new API.

That's the core reason we're getting warnings about shared usage when we do this.  We're making unintentional copies for each task.


Once we're through the hard part, we can regroup and figure out how to implement a subtask system if we need it.

Acknowledged. There is a already a check which errors out if targetSize > 1, i didn't remove that. But sure, let me change the patch to only have Single Target URI support. We can always add back the other changes in next sequence.
This is probably close enough.  I have a question about dbus paths.
Replied to your comment. Thanks

For "this bmc" is the name always going to match the redfish name?

Is there code that always adds a path to the effect of 

/xyz/openbmc_project/update/bmc


I suspect we should be writing a fixed known path here that we always know represents "this bmc" rather than writing the redfish URL path?

In processUpdateRequest(), we map the BMCWEB_REDFISH_MANAGER_URI_NAME to the DBus path /xyz/openbmc_project/software/bmc, as shown in code below. So, we are using fixed known path.

        startUpdate(asyncResp, std::move(payload), memfd, applyTimeNewVal,
                    "/xyz/openbmc_project/software/bmc",
                    "xyz.openbmc_project.Software.Manager");
